Tel.: +34 965 909350; fax: +34 965903454. Graphical abstract The activity and stability of potassium-copper perovskite catalysts for soot combustion were analysed at 450°C in a NOx/O2 gas mixture. Both impregnated (K-Cu/SrTiO3) and substituted (SrKTiCuO3) copper-potassium catalysts were prepared. For comparative purpose, also a potassium substituted catalyst (SrKTiO3) was studied. The high activity of the fresh potassium catalyst (SrKTiO3) is based on the volatile potassium species reaching the surface of soot. However, this catalyst is not useful because potassium is progressively lost during the reaction. Potassium was stabilized by copper and, as a consequence, the two potassium-copper perovskite catalysts present a constant activity for the soot combustion. The activity of the potassium-copper perovskite catalysts, which is maintained during consecutive reactions, is related to their NO2 production capacity. The metal addition method seems to influence the catalysts performance, the substituted catalyst (SrKTiCuO3) being the most active and stable. Keywords Diesel soot combustion Potassium-copper catalyst Perovskite 1 Introduction Diesel engines present different advantages in comparison with Otto engines, such as lower fuel consumption, lower CO2 production and lower emissions of unburned hydrocarbon and carbon monoxide. However, diesel engines generate significant amounts of soot and NOx [1]. As a consequence of the effects of soot and NOx on human health and on the environment, the regulations on vehicle emissions have become more stringent [2] and most of them require control strategies to meet the standards. Many options for the removal of soot from diesel exhaust have been considered and the use of filters (DPF), where soot is retained and subsequently eliminated by catalytic combustion, is one of the most extended [3]. Catalytic combustion is used in order to allow soot combustion at the exhaust gas temperature. The catalytic filter regeneration is a very complex process due to the poor soot–catalyst contact and to the wide range of temperatures in the exhaust gases (from 200 to 600°C), which depend on the engine load. Consequently, the catalysts to be used for diesel soot combustion must be active at low temperatures and stable at high temperatures. Also, low-cost materials are very desirable. Different catalytic after-treatment technologies based on the use of DPF filters have been proposed, and the Continuously Regenerating Trap (CRT) seem to be the most promising [1,4], especially for heavy-duty diesel applications. This system consists of a Pt catalyst for the NO oxidation to NO2, which is more oxidizing than NO and O2, and a DPF filter, where soot is collected and oxidised. However, the CRT system presents several drawbacks, such as deactivation by sintering and high cost due to the use of noble metals [5]. An interesting possibility is the use of metal oxides, such as pure ceria [6] or mixed oxides of cerium and rare-earth metals (La and Pr, for instance) [7,8]. These oxides are able to accelerate soot combustion reaction due to the participation of highly reactive oxygen species (active oxygen) present on the surface of the metal oxides. High catalytic activity for soot combustion has been also reported for mixed oxides with perovskite [9–11], spinel [12,13] and hydrotalcite-like structure [14]. The high activity of these oxides could be also related to the participation of suprafacial, weak chemisorbed oxygen, which contributes actively to soot combustion by spillover. Perovskite-type oxides (general formula ABO3) would be a valuable alternative for catalytic combustion of soot, since they are cheap and thermally stable. This oxide can tolerate substitutions at both cation sites: (i) the partial substitution of A cation by foreign cations with different oxidation states gives rise to a change in the oxidation state of the B-site cations, and/or to the creation of structural defects such as anionic or cationic vacancies to maintain the electroneutrality of the solid and, (ii) the partial substitution of B cation can improve both the structure stability and the catalytic behaviour. In a previous work, strontium and magnesium titanates with perovskite structures have proved to be more effective than alumina as copper support for catalytic soot combustion in a NOx/O2 atmosphere [15]. The better performance of the copper-containing SrTiO3 catalysts with regard to those of Cu/alumina has been mainly attributed to the improved redox properties of copper due to a strong interaction between copper and the perovskite support. Additionally, the catalytic activity is affected by the copper addition method, the copper-substituted perovskites being more active than those with impregnated copper [16]. As the same time, it was also observed that the addition of alkali metals to the catalyst formulation offers substantial benefit for soot combustion [17]. Potassium is a well known catalyst for carbon gasification and, consequently, it was used as catalysts for soot combustion [11,18–20]. It has been suggested that alkali metals, like potassium, are able to improve the catalyst/soot contact by increasing the surface mobility [21,22]. Another positive effect of potassium is related to its electron donor properties, which can increase the oxygen reactivity of the M–O bond. However, the use of potassium as a catalyst for diesel soot combustion presents some drawbacks; one of the most important is the loss of activity by evaporation or decomposition of the active species at elevated temperatures [19,20]. In the case of the SrTiO3 perovskites, when Sr is partially substituted by K, or when K is added by impregnation to the perovskite, a more active catalyst for soot combustion is obtained [23]. The low stability of metallic potassium however, limits the use of potassium-based catalyst for soot combustion. Thus, to avoid or minimize this drawback, the introduction of stabilizers has been studied [24]. Recently, it has been observed that the incorporation of potassium into the perovskite structure increases its stability during the soot-O2 reaction in comparison with impregnated catalysts [25]. In a NOx atmosphere, the authors [20] concluded that fresh potassium catalysts are more active than copper catalysts, but copper is stable under reaction conditions while potassium suffers deactivation at temperatures higher than 500°C. To complete this study, this paper analyses the activity and stability of two potassium-copper perovskite catalysts for diesel soot combustion at mild temperatures (T <500°C) in a NOx/O2 gas mixture. The objective is to determine the effect of the metal addition method on the catalyst performance, paying special attention to their stability. To achieve this goal, potassium and copper were either impregnated on the perovskite (K-Cu/SrTiO3) or introduced into the perovskite structure by partial substitution of Sr and Ti (Sr0.8K0.2Ti0.9Cu0.1O3) during the sol–gel process used for the metal oxides synthesis. For the sake of comparison, a substituted potassium-perovskite catalyst (Sr0.8K0.2TiO3) [20] and an alumina supported Pt catalyst have been studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The substituted catalysts (Sr0.8K0.2Ti0.9Cu0.1O3 and Sr0.8K0.2TiO3, referred to as SrKTiCuO3 and SrKTiO3, respectively) and the bare perovskite (SrTiO3) were prepared by sol–gel method using H2O2, citric acid, titanium (IV) isopropylate and aqueous solutions of Sr, K and Cu nitrates in suitable proportions [25]. The titanium precursor was dissolved in isopropyl alcohol and dropped into a water solution of citric acid at 50°C. After that, hydrogen peroxide and citric acid were added until the precipitate was dissolved, following by the addition of Sr, K and Cu nitrates (Ti:citric acid ratio was 1:2.5). The solution was evaporated to produce a syrup which was dried at 110°C for 12h and calcined at 850°C for 6h. The preparation of bare perovskite (SrTiO3) was carried out following the described procedure but without copper and/or potassium nitrate addition. For the impregnated catalyst (K-Cu/SrTiO3), the SrTiO3 perovskite was first prepared using the sol–gel method and afterwards, copper and potassium were added by excess solution impregnation. The solvent was removed by air bubbling, and once apparently dries, the samples were heated in static air at 110°C for 12h and finally calcinated at 700°C in air for 5h. A 1wt.%Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by excess solution impregnation of γ-Al2O3 (88m2/g) using Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 as the precursor, following the same procedure used for the other impregnated catalysts (dried at 110°C for 12h and calcinated at 700°C in air for 5h). 2.2 Catalysts characterization The BET surface area of the samples was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms data by applying the BET equation. The adsorption isotherms were carried out at −196°C in a volumetric set up (Autosorb 1, Quantachrome), after degassing the samples at 250°C for 4h. The metal content (potassium and/or copper) of the fresh and used (after several reactions at 450°C) catalysts was determined by ICP-OES (Pelkin Elmer Optimal 300). For this purpose, copper and/or potassium were extracted with a boiling 6M HCl solution during 8h. X-ray difractograms of the samples were recorded in a Seifert powder diffractometer, using CuKα radiation. The diffractograms were registered between 2θ angles from 20° to 80°, with a step of 0.02° and a time per step of 3s. XPS characterization was carried out in a VG-Microtech Multilab electron spectrometer using a Mg-Kα (1253.6eV) radiation source. To obtain the XPS spectra, the pressure of the analysis chamber was maintained at 5·10−10 mbar. The binding energy (BE) scale was adjusted by setting the C1s transition at 284.6eV. The spectra were collected and processed by using the software Peak-Fit of the spectrometer. Non linear least-squares fitting algorithm was applied using peaks with a mix of Gaussian–Lorenzian shape. Temperature Programmed Reduction experiments were carried out with H2 (H2-TPR) in a Micromeritics device, model Pulse ChemiSorb 2705. In a typical experiment, 20mg of sample were heated at 10°C/min from 25 to 900°C under a 5% H2/Ar flow (35ml/min, P total =1atm), and the H2 consumption was monitored with a TCD detector. A CuO reference sample supplied by Micromeritics has been used to quantify the H2 consumption. 2.3 Catalysts activity and stability Soot combustion experiments were performed in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure under a gas flow (500ml/min, GSVH 30,000h−1) containing 500ppm NO x , 5% O2, balanced with N2 for NOx-soot reaction or 5% O2, balanced with N2 for O2-soot reaction. The soot used is a carbon black from Cabot (Vulcan XC72). Catalyst–soot mixtures (80mg of catalyst+20mg of soot+300mg SiC) were prepared in the so-called loose-contact mode (as it provides information with practical relevance) [26]. The gas composition was monitored by specific NDIR-UV gas analyzers for NO, NO2, CO, CO2 and O2, recording the gas composition every 10s. Six hour-isothermal soot combustion experiments were performed at 450°C in this set up. The catalysts stability was determined by carrying out several consecutives isothermal reactions using the same parcel of catalyst. The number of consecutive experiments performed (5 or 6) depends on the catalyst, and the criterion used for stopping the sequence of experiments was to obtain two consecutive reactions with identical catalytic performance. Temperature Programmed Reactions (TPR, from 25 to 750°C at 10°C/min) using both NOx/O2/N2 and O2/N2 gas mixtures were also carried out. In order to determine the activity of catalysts for NO2 production, blank experiments (without soot) in the NOx/O2/N2 gas mixture were also performed using only the catalysts. In soot combustion experiments (TPR and isothermal reaction at 450°C), the conversion of soot was determined from the amount of CO and CO2 emitted. The parameter “t 80%”, which is the time needed to reach 80% soot conversion during the isothermal reaction at 450°C, was estimated from the conversion data. Finally, the selectivity towards CO2 formation with regard to the total CO x emitted was determined by using the following equation: Selectivity CO2 (%)=CO2/CO x (%)=100·CO2/(CO+CO2) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 Metal content and surface area The potassium and/or copper content of fresh catalysts, determined by ICP-OES, and the BET surface areas are shown in Table 1 . The copper and/or potassium content is about 4% for the impregnated catalysts (K-Cu/SrTiO3), and also for the potassium-substituted catalyst (SrKTiO3). However, the copper and potassium content is slightly lower than 4 for the potassium-copper substituted catalyst (SrKTiCuO3). The BET surface area of the bare support is 11m2/g and, as observed previously for some other copper-containing SrTiO3 perovskite catalysts [15], the potassium and/or copper-containing catalysts present slightly lower BET surface areas. 3.1.2 XRD characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns for the fresh catalysts. For all catalysts, the peaks corresponding to SrTiO3 perovskite structure are observed. Additionally, low intensity peaks correspond to SrCO3 (formed by carbonation of surface strontium oxide during atmospheric exposure) and TiO2 (rutile phase) are identified mainly for SrTiO3 and SrKTiCuO3. Surface CuO is observed in the impregnated catalyst (K-Cu/SrTiO3) but not in the substituted catalyst (SrKTiCuO3), which means that copper is properly incorporated within the perovskite lattice and/or if any CuO is present, it is not detected by XRD because its size must be under the detection limit of the technique. 3.1.3 XPS analysis The analysis of the XPS data indicates the presence of Sr, K, Ti, Cu, O and C on the surface of the catalysts. Table 2 compiles the binding energies of the Sr 3d3/2, Sr 3d5/2, Ti 2p3/2 and Cu 2p3/2 electronic transitions for the catalysts and for the bare support. The binding energies of the Sr 3d electronic transitions were consistent with the values reported for Sr2+ [27]. It has been indicated that peaks at 134.3 and 132.7eV correspond to the Sr3d3/2 and Sr3d5/2 electronic transitions in SrTiO3 [28]. The peak at around 136.0eV [29], expected for SrO, has not been identified in any sample. The binding energy values of Sr3d5/2 and Sr3d3/2 transition for substituted catalysts (SrKTiO3 and SrKTiCuO3) are lower than those observed in the impregnated catalyst (K-Cu/SrTiO3), probably due to the changes in electron density distribution due to the presence of foreign metals in the crystal structure. For titanium, only one peak is observed at 457.8eV, which corresponds to Ti4+ cation [22]. As for SrO, the expected band of TiO2 is not observed. For copper catalysts, it has to be taken into account that reduced copper species, such as metallic copper or Cu2O usually appear below 933eV [31] meanwhile copper species with Cu+2 cations show XPS bands above 933eV. Thus, for K-Cu/SrTiO3 catalyst, the main band appears at ca. 933.7ev, which means that, as expected, Cu+2 species are present in this catalyst. However, the main band for SrKTiCuO3 is observed at ca. 932.6eV, which seems to suggest the presence of reduced copper species (Cu2O or metallic copper). The Auger parameter (α), calculated for SrKTiCuO3 and K-Cu/SrTiO3 catalysts was 1851.1 and 1851.5eV, respectively. These values indicate that Cu2+ species must be present in both potassium-copper catalysts. A revision of the literature data [32–35] reveals that copper species (Cu2+, Cu1+ and Cu0) inserted in bulk phases can be differentiated by their characteristics binding energy in addition with their Auger parameters. However, when copper is highly dispersed and in intimate contact with supports, as is the case of the catalysts under study, Cu2p3/2 energies and particularly Cu Auger parameters may significantly differ from the corresponding bulk values and, consequently, the assignation of XPS contributions is more difficult. Thus, Fernandez-García et al. [36] observed that for a Cu/CeOx/Al2O3 catalyst (reduced with H2 at 350°C, which is enough to obtain reduced copper species) the Cu2p3/2 XPS band appears at 932.7eV being the Auger parameter 1851.3eV. These values are very similar to those observed for the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst suggesting, again, the presence of reduced copper species or copper species with a large electron density. Considering the electronegativity values for copper and potassium (1.9 and 0.8, respectively), an electron transfer from potassium to copper could be suggested. In this situation, an increase in the electron density on copper would be expected causing a shift to lower energy of the copper XPS band. Thus, this hypothesis seems to explain the low BE value for XPS band found for substituted catalysts (932.7eV), and, also, the low value of Auger parameter [37]. Fig. 2 shows the XPS spectra of the O1s transition for the catalysts which are similar to those reported for other mixed oxides such as Ce x La1−x O2 (x =25, 50 or 75) [38], SrTiCuO3 perovskites [16] and La1−x Sr x MO3 (M=Co0.77Bi0.20Pd0.03; 0≤ x ≤0.8) [39]. After the bands deconvolution, two contributions at approximately 529 and 531eV are identified: (i) the O1s band at ca. 529eV corresponds to lattice oxygen of metal oxides [30], and (ii) the band at ca. 531eV has been assigned to adsorbed oxygen species (O2 −2), surface carbonates (CO3 −2), and/or hydroxyl groups (OH). The intensity of the band at ca. 531ev appreciably increases for the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst (Fig. 2a), indicating the presence of a larger amount of surface oxygen species (O2 −2, OH– groups, and/or carbonates) than for the other two catalysts K-Cu/SrTiO3 and SrKTiO3 (Fig. 2b and c). This increase seems to be related with the insertion of a fraction of copper into the perovskite lattice. The partial substitution of Ti+4 by Cu+2 causes an electronic deficiency that could be compensated by the presence of Ti+3 cations and/or the formation of oxygen vacancies [40]. Because the XPS data do not reveal the presence of Ti+3 (Table 2), the electroneutrality of the perovskite has to be achieved by the formation of the oxygen vacancies where surface oxygen species are formed. 3.1.4 H2-TPR results It is well known that copper reducibility plays a key role in the catalytic activity for soot combustion [15,16,41] and, to obtain information about the reducibility of copper species in the catalysts under study, H2-TPR experiments have been carried out. The H2 profiles shown in Fig. 3 reveal that the H2 consumption in the range of 250–550°C, is due to the copper species reduction, as bare perovskite does not show any reduction. The percentage of copper oxide reduced for the two catalysts, estimated from H2 consumption (using CuO as the reference material) and included in Table 1, corresponds to 100% copper reduction (considering that Cu(II) is the copper species being reduced). The TCD signal profile for K-Cu/SrTiO3 catalyst features two peaks which seem to correspond to copper species with different reducibility, with maxima at temperature lower than the observed for the CuO used as reference (290 and 335°C versus 400°C). The position of the maxima indicates the presence of copper oxide with a strong electronic interaction with the perovskite, and for hence more easily reducible [16], because for this catalyst lattice copper is not the main copper species. For the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst, the H2 consumption is observed along a broad range of temperatures between 250 and 550°C, with a main maximum around 350°C followed by other smaller, less defined secondary maximum at ca. 400°C and, finally, by a third, even smaller maximum at ca. 525°C. The maximum located at temperature lower than 400°C, indicates the presence of copper with a strong electronic interaction with the perovskite or to copper incorporated into the lattice as main copper species. It has to be underlined that, though the copper incorporation generates a distortion of the structure creating oxygen vacancies, the coordination of copper keeps being higher than that of the CuO and allows its reduction at lower temperature than CuO used as reference. Considering these H2-TPR profiles, it is concluded that the copper species present in the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst are more difficult to reduce than those present in the K-Cu/SrTiO3 catalyst. 3.2 Catalyst activity and stability for soot combustion 3.2.1 Catalysts activity for soot combustion in TPR conditions For comparative purpose, Figs. 4 and 5 show the soot conversion profiles obtained under O2 and NOx/O2 atmosphere, for uncatalyzed reaction, potassium and copper-potassium perovskites and for the Pt/Al2O3 reference catalyst. In Fig. 4 it is observed that all catalysts tested decrease the range of temperature for soot combustion with O2, except the Pt/Al2O3 reference catalyst. Among perovskite-based catalysts, the K-Cu/SrTiO3 catalyst is the most active one, while SrKTiO3 and SrKTiCuO3 catalysts present similar soot conversion profiles. Fig. 5, reveals that different profiles are observed when NOx is present in the gaseous reaction mixture. Note that all catalysts are active, decreasing the onset temperature for soot oxidation and increasing the reaction rate compared with uncatalyzed reaction and O2-catalyzed reaction (Fig. 4). As will be discussed below, the ability of the catalysts to accelerate the NO2 production (which is more reactive than O2 for soot combustion), explains the higher reaction rate in the presence of NOx. At temperatures lower than 500°C, the SrKTiO3 catalyst is the most active one, being the onset temperature for soot oxidation close to 350°C. However, at temperatures higher than 500°C, the SrKTiO3 catalyst shows a loss of activity. It is also observed that the incorporation of copper increases the onset temperature, but the potassium-copper perovskite catalysts do not present deactivation at temperatures higher than 500°C. 3.2.2 Catalysts activity and stability for soot combustion at 450°C Previous results [20] revealed that potassium is more active than copper in fresh catalysts, but copper is stable under Temperature Programmed Reaction (TPR) conditions (several reactions up to 700°C) while potassium catalysts suffer deactivation at temperatures higher than 500°C. The objective of the present study is to determine the potassium and potassium-copper catalysts performance during soot combustion at temperatures lower than 500°C, which is a range of interest for soot removal from diesel engine exhaust. Following the scheme previously used to study the stability of the catalysts [20], a set of consecutive isothermal experiments at 450°C (using the same parcel of catalyst) has been carried out. It has to be mentioned that the uncatalyzed combustion of the soot does not take place under the experimental conditions used, so, the data corresponding to the uncatalyzed reaction do not appear hereafter. Fig. 6 shows the soot conversion profiles at 450°C obtained for the catalysts under study. It is remarkable that an almost constant conversion profile is found for the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst (Fig. 6a), meanwhile the K-Cu/SrTiO3 catalyst shows a certain degree of deactivation (Fig. 6b). For the SrKTiO3 catalyst, a notable deactivation (Fig. 6c) is shown, as it was also observed for other potassium catalysts [19] and in TPR reaction conditions (see Fig. 5). Additionally, a high selectivity for CO2 (CO2/CO around 90%) is obtained for all catalysts tested. This result was expected based on previous data of copper catalysts [15,16,41]. In order to establish a suitable comparison among the catalysts performance during reaction at 450°C, the t 80% parameter, which is the time required for achieving the 80% soot conversion, has been calculated. In Fig. 7 , these t 80% values for five consecutive reactions of the three catalysts under study have been compared. It is observed that for the first and second reactions, the potassium catalyst (SrKTiO3) is more active than the potassium-copper catalysts, because less time is required to achieve the 80% soot conversion. However, after the third reaction, the activity of potassium catalyst is lost and the t 80% values are notably larger than for potassium-copper catalysts. It has to be highlighted that the potassium-copper catalysts present an almost constant activity during the five reactions. Between the two potassium-copper catalysts, the substituted one seems to be the most interesting as it presents slightly lower values for t 80%: 97 and 113min for SrKTiCuO3 and K-Cu/SrTiO3, respectively. These activity results have to be related with potassium stability during reaction. Table 3 compiles the metal content of the used catalysts. After five reactions, the potassium catalyst loses a large fraction of potassium (see Table 1 for fresh catalysts), which explains the loss of activity. In the presence of copper, the stability of potassium increases, mainly for the substituted catalyst, for which 80% of potassium is maintained after the consecutive isothermal reactions. Thus, in a general sense, the performance of the catalysts for soot combustion seems to depend on the potassium stability: the catalyst, which is able to keep a large amount of potassium during the reaction, presents the most stable catalytic performance. An important issue for catalyzed soot combustion under NOx/O2 is the NO2 formation as NO2 is much more reactive than NO and, consequently it will oxidize soot at lower temperatures. Therefore, the formation of NO2 (by Reaction 1) will initiate soot combustion. (1) NO + 1 2 O 2 ↔ NO 2 In order to obtain information about the NO2 formation, blank experiments were carried out, and the NO2 profiles are shown in Fig. 8 . The potassium catalyst (SrKTiO3) shows a low activity for the NO oxidation to NO2 meanwhile, in the presence of copper, the NO oxidation takes place to a significant extent. These results are of relevance because the different activity for the NO oxidation to NO2 implies differences in the activity for soot combustion. It has been found that the temperature for the maximum production of NO2 (T maxNO2 (°C)) determines the catalyst activity for soot combustion [15,16]. For the catalysts under study, T maxNO2 shows the sequence: SrKTiCuO3 <K-Cu/SrTiO3 <SrKTiO3. This sequence corresponds with that observed for soot conversion during the 4th and 5th reactions, when the stability is tentatively achieved. Thus, it could be concluded that the catalyst activity for NO2 production explains the activity trend for soot combustion at 450°C during the last two reactions. However, paying attention to the two first reaction cycles, the soot conversion seems to be controlled by the presence of potassium, the potassium perovskite catalyst being the most active. Anyway, this high activity is not useful from a practical point of view due to low stability of potassium during reaction process. Considering our background in the study of the copper-catalyzed NOx-soot combustion [15,16,20,39], it seems that the role of the copper species depends on the catalyst. Thus, for copper-perovskite impregnated catalysts (Cu/SrTiO3 or Cu/MgTiO3), surface CuO seems to be the active site working throughout a redox mechanism which involves the reduction and oxidation of copper oxide. On the contrary, active sites are not necessarily related to the Cu(II) for copper-perovskite substituted catalysts (SrTiCuO3 and MgTiCuO3) for which lattice copper promotes significantly the catalytic performance of the mixed oxide SrTiCuO3 by creation of surface active sites (weakly bound oxygen). For potassium-copper catalysts, a similar conclusion seems to be extracted. Thus, considering the characterization results (DRX and XPS) and the catalytic performance results, it seems that active sites in K-Cu/SrTiO3 are related with the presence of surface (reducible) CuO, meanwhile, active sites for substituted catalyst (SrKTiCuO3) are linked to the promotion of lattice copper, affected by the concomitant presence of potassium, through the creation of surface actives sites (weakly bound oxygen). To analyse further the performance of the catalysts, the NO2 slip (defined like the NO2 emitted during the soot combustion experiments) is presented in Fig. 9a for SrKTiCuO3 catalyst, which is the most active and stable catalyst. As a reference, the data obtained for a Pt/Al2O3 catalyst are shown in Fig. 9b. The soot conversion profiles and the NO2 produced during blank experiments carried out in the absence of catalyst have been also included. The NO2-slip demonstrates that only a fraction of the NO2 generated is used for soot oxidation. Thus, the difference between the NO2 produced and the NO2-slip, is the NO2 which is reacting with soot. In the experimental conditions used, the NO2 production reaches the thermodynamic equilibrium at 385 and 445°C for Pt/Al2O3 and SrKTiCuO3, respectively. At higher temperatures, the NO2 production decreases due to the thermodynamic equilibrium. The SrKTiCuO3 catalyst (Fig. 9a) presents a lower activity for the NO oxidation to NO2 than Pt/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 9b), however, a low soot conversion is observed for the platinum catalyst, probably due to the low reactivity of the soot at the NO2 maximum temperature. Consequently, a significant NO2 slip is shown by Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, meanwhile for SrKTiCuO3 catalyst the NO2-slip is not observed. By comparing the soot conversion profile obtained using NO2 +O2 as reaction mixture and in the absence of catalyst, it is observed that for the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst both profiles are similar up to 420°C, indicating that the amount of NO2 generated is enough to oxidize the soot. However, at temperatures above 420°C, the NO2 produced seems to be more effective because the soot conversion in the presence of the catalyst is higher than soot conversion in the NO2 +O2 gas mixture. In this range of temperature, a high concomitant decrease in the NO2-slip is observed. Thus, between 420 and 500°C, the catalyst is able to carry out the NO to NO2 re-oxidation (Reaction 1). However, it was estimated that almost 30 cycles of NO to NO2 oxidation reactions would be necessary to achieve the soot conversion percentage. Therefore, the contribution of O2 seems to be required to explain the soot conversion observed. For the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst, the same pathway is shown: the main reaction able to decrease the soot combustion temperature, between 400 and 500°C, is soot oxidation with NO2 followed by the NO to NO2 re-oxidation. As for Pt/Al2O3, the contribution of the soot combustion with O2 also has to be taken into account. The results above described reveal that the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst produces a higher amount of NO2, but it is not properly used for soot combustion, and therefore a significant NO2-slip is observed. On the contrary, the NO2 produced by the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst is more properly used for soot combustion and an almost null NO2-slip is observed. The low efficiency for soot combustion of the NO2 generated by Pt/Al2O3 seems to be related to the low reactivity of the soot at the low temperature at which NO2 is produced. Finally, the NO2 slip for the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst during the reactions at 450°C (reactions 1 and 4) is shown in Fig. 10 . The NO2 is not observed up to 60% soot conversion is achieved and, above, the NO2-slip increases until the soot is almost entirely burned out. The almost constant profiles observed for the NO2-slip seems to justify the stability of the catalyst and, it is confirmed that the performance of the SrKTiCuO3 catalyst for soot combustion is related to the NO2 production in reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions From the analysis of the catalytic activity and stability for soot combustion of the potassium-copper and the potassium perovskite catalysts, the following conclusions have been obtained: - The decrease in soot combustion activity at 450°C shown by the potassium-perovskite catalyst is due to the loss of potassium during reaction. As a consequence, the catalyst is not useful from a practical point of view. - The incorporation of copper into the potassium perovskite catalyst improves the potassium stability during reaction at 450°C. - The higher activity shown by the potassium-copper perovskite catalysts is related to their NO2 production. - The metal addition method seems to influence the performance of catalysts, the substituted catalyst (SrKTiCuO3) being the most active and stable. coredata.dc:description: The activity and stability of potassium-copper perovskite catalysts for soot combustion were analysed at 450°C in a NOx/O2 gas mixture. Both impregnated (K-Cu/SrTiO3) and substituted (SrKTiCuO3) copper-potassium catalysts were prepared. For comparative purpose, also a potassium substituted catalyst (SrKTiO3) was studied. The high activity of the fresh potassium catalyst (SrKTiO3) is based on the volatile potassium species reaching the surface of soot. However, this catalyst is not useful because potassium is progressively lost during the reaction. Potassium was stabilized by copper and, as a consequence, the two potassium-copper perovskite catalysts present a constant activity for the soot combustion. The activity of the potassium-copper perovskite catalysts, which is maintained during consecutive reactions, is related to their NO2 production capacity. The metal addition method seems to influence the catalysts performance, the substituted catalyst (SrKTiCuO3) being the most active and stable.
coredata.dc:title: Potassium-copper perovskite catalysts for mild temperature diesel soot combustion
